articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document, titled 'EPHEMERIS' and dated March 1983, appears to be a publication from 'SJAA', likely an astronomical organization. It features an astronomical photograph of a globular cluster, indicating content relevant to celestial observation or club activities for the month.

articles.title: CALENDAR
articles.summary: This document outlines a calendar of astronomical events and meetings for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) during March and April, including star parties, a multi-night Messier Marathon, general meetings, and an Astronomy Day celebration. It also provides contact information for the association's officers, board members, and the monthly publication, EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article announces the 1983 Messier Marathon, scheduled for March 11-13 and March 18-20, with the earlier date preferred due to lunar conditions. This annual star party focuses on observing Messier objects, although other general observing and photography are also encouraged. Participants are invited to observe from Loma Prieta Mtn. in the Santa Cruz Mountains, with detailed directions provided, and advised to dress warmly.

articles.title: BY D. MEDLOCK
articles.summary: The South Bay amateur astronomical community is invited to a general meeting on March 19th at 8:00 PM in Alumnai Science Hall, Room 102, University of Santa Clara. William Unruh, a historian from Lick Observatory, will give a slide presentation on the observatory's colorful history and its significance in astronomical research. Attendees are encouraged to bring family and friends for an enjoyable evening.

articles.title: BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland successfully recovered Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) on February 3, 1983, 205 days after its last timing prior to conjunction. Though faint and lacking color, the GRS was noted to be larger than in recent years, offering hope for improved visibility. The report also details the Spot's appearance, its location relative to Jupiter's belts, and provides specific observing tips along with a schedule of meridian timings.

articles.title: OMEGA CENTAURI STAR-PARTY
articles.summary: The article announces an Omega Centauri Star-Party organized by the Peninsula Astronomical Society for Saturday, March 12, inviting members from several other astronomical associations. The event will be held at Chews Ridge, a dark-sky site at 5000ft, ideal for observing deep-sky objects like the globular cluster Omega Centauri and the radio galaxy Centaurus A, which are well-placed for viewing on this date. Attendees are encouraged to bring their telescopes, and members will share equipment with those who don't have one, promising fantastic views of difficult objects.

articles.title: BY BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article provides several brief updates on space and astronomy news, covering the safe reentry of the Cosmos 1402 satellite and a delay in the sixth Space Shuttle launch due to a hydrogen leak. Key developments include San Jose aiding Lick Observatory by mandating low-pressure sodium lights, the successful launch of the IRAS satellite, and plans for the STS-7 landing and Japanese astronaut selection.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article reports on the recovery of Periodic Comet Pons-Winnecke (1983b) by B. Everhart, marking his first comet recovery, while also debunking 'Comet 1983a' as non-existent due to inconsistent observations. It also briefly notes Comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko fading and mentions upcoming discussions on comets discovered by William Bradfield.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: This article details the discovery circumstances of two comets by William Bradfield: Comet Bradfield (1975d) and Comet Bradfield (1976d). It describes when and where each comet was found, its magnitude, and its position relative to the sun and moon. The text also discusses the comets' pre-discovery visibility, highlighting how the 1975d comet could have been seen earlier, especially from the Southern Hemisphere, and the 1976d comet's limited visibility from the Northern Hemisphere, compounded by the presence of Comet West.

articles.title: BY FRANK DIBBELL
articles.summary: This article revives the 'club member on the street' interview series, featuring Tom Ahl, a club member since 1981. Tom shares his lifelong astronomical journey, from early sci-fi interests and a challenging attempt to build a telescope, to his renewed passion in the Navy and eventual purchase of a 13.1" Dobsonian that led him to join the club. He discusses learning the night sky with his scope, future aspirations in astrophotography, and his desire for the club to increase public involvement.

articles.title: BY BRUCE DE GRAAF
articles.summary: Bruce De Graaf introduces a new column for beginner astronomers, aiming to guide readers in independently setting up and enjoying the night sky with a telescope. The inaugural column focuses on achieving polar alignment for motor-driven telescope mounts, a crucial step for accurate star tracking, and provides a simple, unique method for locating Polaris and aligning the R.A. axis.

articles.title: Telescope Alignment Instructions
articles.summary: This article details the 'Fingerhut technique,' a precise method for polar aligning a telescope, acknowledging that Polaris is not perfectly coincident with the celestial North Pole. It provides step-by-step instructions for adjusting declination, right ascension, and using a provided table to determine the time of Polaris's eastern elongation for accurate alignment. The goal is to ensure images remain in view at high magnifications by properly aligning the telescope mount.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article by Don Machholz provides guidance on determining suitable dark observing times for astronomical activities by graphing twilight times for 37 degrees North Latitude. It defines 'dark enough' as when the sun is 15 degrees below the horizon, useful for planning events like star parties, observing the Perseids, and Astronomy Day.

articles.title: The shirts between Standard Time and Daylight Savings Time is shown, this increases the spread to four hours for evening twilight (roughly 6PM to 10PM) while it decreases the morning twilight times to a narrow range of two hours (roughly 4AM to 6AM).
articles.summary: The article highlights the impact of the shift between Standard Time and Daylight Saving Time on twilight durations. It indicates that evening twilight expands to a four-hour window (roughly 6 PM to 10 PM), while morning twilight condenses to a two-hour window (roughly 4 AM to 6 AM). These shifts are illustrated with charts for 37°N Latitude.

articles.title: BY LARRY WEBSTER
articles.summary: Larry Webster introduces himself as an experienced amateur astronomer and telescope maker, offering his expertise to the SJAA club to foster a central point for information exchange and problem-solving related to telescope making and usage. He then presents a detailed technical guide on how to diagnose and address telescope pointing errors caused by a lack of perpendicularity between the Right Ascension (RA) and Declination (DEC) axes in a German equatorial mount, describing a sensitive test method.

articles.title: Step 2
articles.summary: This document, titled "Step 2," describes a method for measuring and correcting the alignment error between a telescope's Right Ascension (RA) and Declination (DEC) axes. It involves using a lined piece of paper to track the movement of two points (A and B) as the RA shaft rotates, then applying a provided formula to calculate the alignment error. The author notes achieving high precision (less than 2 arc minutes) and invites contributions for subsequent installments of the article.

articles.title: BY JEFF HORNE
articles.summary: This article by Jeff Horne presents a humorous and satirical list of characteristics that "Real Astronomers" supposedly do not possess or engage in. It playfully pokes fun at various aspects of the amateur astronomy hobby, including equipment choices, observing habits, social etiquette, and common misconceptions, all from an informal and observational perspective.

articles.title: Real Astronomers don't own Kellners.
articles.summary: This article humorously critiques common behaviors and attitudes within the amateur astronomy community through a satirical list of things "Real Astronomers don't" do, concluding that true astronomers don't concern themselves with such labels. Separately, it provides an official announcement regarding updated membership renewal rates for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), including options with Sky & Telescope magazine subscriptions.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document contains a membership application and renewal form for the SJAA, detailing options for full, junior, or bulletin subscriber memberships along with associated fees. Additionally, it announces the upcoming "3RD ANNUAL BAY-AREA ASTRONOMICAL AUCTION."

articles.title: SATURDAY, APRIL 30TH 1983
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association announced an astronomical equipment auction scheduled for April 30, 1983, at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. This "bigger and better" event promised a wide variety of new and used astronomical items, including telescopes, eyepieces, and camera equipment, all to be auctioned at bargain prices.

articles.title: ANY ONE MAY BID --- ANY ONE MAY SELL
articles.summary: This document outlines the procedures for an upcoming auction, providing detailed instructions for both bidders and sellers. Sellers are advised to register items, set minimum bids, and consider preregistration by March 10th for inclusion in a published list, with a 10% SJAA fee supporting amateur astronomical activities. Bidders must register for a number and complete payments by the auction's end, and directions to the event location are also included.

articles.title: ITEM PREREGISTRATION FORM
articles.summary: This document is an item preregistration form for an auction, providing fields for item details, minimum bids, and contact information. Participants are instructed to send the completed form to the SJAA Auction address or call the provided phone numbers in Oakland or San Jose.

articles.title: SEC. C 95/124
articles.summary: This document fragment contains only a header identifier, 'SEC. C 95/124', and the word 'Recco'. The provided content is extremely sparse, indicating that the original image was mostly blank and offers no substantial information for analysis.

articles.title: ITEMS ALREADY PRE-REGISTERED
articles.summary: This document lists items already pre-registered for the 3rd Annual Bay-Area Astronomical Auction, including a variety of telescopes, lenses, astronomical equipment, books, meteorites, and posters, each with a minimum bid. It also provides directions to the auction location and emphasizes that this is only a partial list of items available.

articles.title: SATURDAY, APRIL 30th, 1983
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association is hosting its annual astronomical auction on Saturday, April 30th, 1983, at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. Starting with registration at 5:30 PM, the event promises a wide array of new and used astronomical equipment, including books, mirrors, eyepieces, telescopes, and camera gear, all offered at bargain prices. Attendees are encouraged to sell their items and check their want lists for one of the Bay Area's most enjoyable amateur astronomy events.
